facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1952 was filed by special leave from the Judgment and Decree dated 10th November 1948 of the High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1952. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th November 1948 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal from Original Decree No. 274 of 1945 arising out of the decree dated the 17th March 1945 of the Court of Revenue Judge, Bombay in Suits Nos. 7 and 23 of 1943.

facts.text: The appeal arises out of decree dated 17th March 1945 of the Court of Revenue Judge, Bombay in Suits Nos. 7 and 23 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1952. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th November 1948 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal from Original Decree No. 274 of 1945 arising out of the decree dated the 17th March 1945 of the Court of Revenue Judge, Bombay in Suits Nos. 7 and 23 of 1943.

facts.text: The lands were originally known as Foras lands, rights settled by Bombay Act No. VI of 1851.

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision in this appeal is as to the liability of certain lands situated within the City of Bombay to be assessed to revenue under the Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876. These lands were originally known as Foras lands, and the rights of the occupants of 1313 those lands were settled by Bombay Act No. VI of 1851, called the Foras Act.

facts.text: Between 1864 and 1867 the Government acquired these lands for the B.B. C.I. Railway under Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857.

anchor.surface_text: What these rights are, is a matter in companytroversy between the parties, and will be presently companysidered. Between 1864 and 1867 the Government acquired these lands for the purpose of the B.B. C.I. Railway under the provisions of Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857.

facts.text: On 22-11-1938 these lands were sold by the Governor-General to Lady Pochkhanawalla and others as joint tenants under a deed, Exhibit A.

anchor.surface_text: On 22-11-1938 these lands, being numberlonger required for the purpose of the Railway, were sold by the Governor-General to Lady Pochkhanawalla and others as joint tenants under a deed, Exhibit A.

facts.text: On 28-3-1939 the survivor of the purchasers under Exhibit A conveyed the lands in trust under Exhibit B, respondents are trustees.

anchor.surface_text: On 28-3-1939 the survivor of the purchasers under Exhibit A companyveyed the lands in trust under Exhibit B, and the respondents are the trustees appointed under that deed.

facts.text: In April 1942 the appellant issued notices to respondents proposing to levy assessment under Bombay Act No. II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1942 the appellant acting under the provisions of Bombay Act No. II of 1876, issued numberices to the respondents proposing to levy assessment on the lands at the rates mentioned therein, and calling for their representation.

facts.text: Respondents denied right to assess and instituted two suits before Revenue Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In their reply, the respondents denied the right of the appellant to assess the lands to revenue, and followed it up by instituting two suits before the Revenue Judge for establishing their rights.

facts.text: Revenue Judge held lands vested in Government free from liability to pay assessment after acquisition, granted declaration no right to levy.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Judge held that as a result of the land acquisition proceedings between 1864 and 1867, the lands vested in the Government freed from any liability to pay assessment, and that when the Governor-General transferred them under 1314 Exhibit A without reserving the right to assess them, the purchasers had the right to hold them without any liability to pay revenue.

facts.text: High Court of Bombay dismissed appeal, held Foras Act limited assessment, acquisition extinguished right even within limit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defendants to the High Court of Bombay, it was held by Chagla, C.J., Bhagwati, J. companycurring, that Act No. VI of 1851 imposed a specific limit on the right of the Government to levy assessments on the lands in question, that, further, by reason of the land acquisition proceedings the right of the Provincial Government to levy assessment even within the limits prescribed by Act No. VI of 1851 was extinguished

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 28, 1955 by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta, with him , for the appellant. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India and Jamshedji Kanga,,  R. J. Kolah and Rajinder Narain, with them , for the respondents. 1955. February 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.

facts.text: Under Foras Act 1851, maximum assessment was 9 reas per burga, as alleged by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In their plaints, they alleged that under the provisions of the Foras Act the maximum assessment leviable on the lands was 9 reas per burga, and that the Government had numberright to enhance it

facts.text: Land acquisition proceedings 1864-1867 extinguished State's right to levy assessment, as claimed by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: that the effect of the land acquisition proceedings between 1864 and 1867 was to extinguish the right of the State to levy even this assessment

facts.text: Purchasers under Exhibit A entitled to hold without liability to revenue, as claimed.

anchor.surface_text: and that further, having purchased the properties absolutely from the Governor-General under Exhibit A. they were entitled to bold them without any liability to pay revenue thereon.

facts.text: Island of Bombay ceded by Portugal to British Crown in 1661 as dowry.

anchor.surface_text: The Island of Bombay once formed part of the Portuguese Domi- nions in India. In 1661 when Princess Infant Catherine was married to King Charles 11 of England, it was ceded by the King of Portugal to the British Crown as dowry

facts.text: King Charles II granted Island to East India Company by Royal Charter dated 27th March 1668.

anchor.surface_text: and by a Royal Charter dated 27th March 1668 King Charles 11 granted it to the East India Company.

facts.text: During 18th Century, East India Company reclaimed lands and invited cultivation, payments called Foras.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from Wardens Report on the Landed Tenures in Bombay and Le Mesuriers Report on the Foras lands, that during the 18th Century the East India Company started  1   1937  L.R. 64 I.A. 334.  2  1885 I.L.R. 9 Bom. 483, 488, 1317 reclaiming these lands, and invited the inhabitants to cultivate them

facts.text: Assessment on Foras lands was 9 reas per burga from 1858 until acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the assessment payable on these lands at that time was 9 reas per burga, and Exhibit N shows that it was at that rate that the assessment was companylected from 1858 until the lands were acquired by the Government in land acquisition proceedings.

facts.text: Court holds under Foras Act, assessment limited to amount then payable (9 reas per burga).

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the respondents that under the Foras Act they acquired a specific right to hold the lands on payment of assessment number exceeding what was then payable, must, therefore, be accepted

facts.text: Land acquisition under Act VI of 1857 vested lands in Government free from other estates, but Government's right to assess not extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: It must accordingly be held that the effect of the land acquisition proceedings was only to extinguish the rights of the occupants in the lands and to vest them absolutely in the Government, that the right of the latter to levy assessment was number the subject-matter of those proceedings

facts.text: Exhibit A conveys lands absolutely but subject to payment of all cesses, taxes, rates, assessments.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A has to be companystrued in the light of these principles. As already stated, there is numberrecital in the deed that the purchasers are entitled to, hold the lands free of assessment. On the other hand, it  1   1859 12 Moore P.C. 473, 496, 497 14 E.R. 991, 1000. 1329 expressly provides that the properties will be subject to the payment of all cesses, taxes, rates, assessments, dues and duties whatsoever number or hereafter to become payable in respect thereof

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no limitation on Government's right to assess under section 8 of Act II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, it must be held that the right of the appellant to levy assessment under section 8 of Act No. II of 1876 is number limited by any right in the respondents.

facts.text: Foras Act repealed in 1870 by Act No. XIV of 1870.

anchor.surface_text: The Foras Act was repealed in 1870 by Act No. XIV of 1870 long prior to the date of Exhibit A

facts.text: Respondents are superior holders under Act II of 1876, as proceeded on basis agreed by parties.

anchor.surface_text: It was on the footing that the respondents were superior holders as defined in the Act, that the appellant issued numberices to them in April 1942. In their reply numberices and in the plaints, the respondents did number dispute that position

facts.text: In 1804, Company resumed some Foras lands, suit by Sheik Abdul Ambly failed.

anchor.surface_text: In 1804, the Company resumed some of the Foras lands for settling persons displaced in the Town area, and that resulted in a suit by one Sheik Abdul Ambly, wherein the right of the Company to resume the lands was challenged.

issues.text: Whether the lands situated within the City of Bombay are liable to be assessed to revenue under the Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision in this appeal is as to the liability of certain lands situated within the City of Bombay to be assessed to revenue under the Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876.

issues.text: Whether the respondents qualify as superior holders under section 3(4) of Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876 such that assessment proceedings under section 8 apply.

anchor.surface_text: In the argument before us, the contention was sought to be raised for the first time by the learned Attorney-General that the proceedings taken by the Collector under section 8 were incompetent, as that section would apply only to lands held by superior holders, that the definition of superior holier in section 3  4  as meaning the person having the highest title under the Provincial Government to any land in the City of Bombay

issues.text: Whether the respondents have established a specific right in limitation of the right of Government to assess the lands under section 8 of Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: the burden was on the person who pleaded a limitation on the right of the State to assess, to clearly and unequivocally establish it.

issues.text: Whether the Foras Act No. VI of 1851 confers a specific right limiting assessment to 9 reas per burga on the lands.

anchor.surface_text: Taking first the Foras Act For a correct appreciation of its provisions, it is necessary to refer -Co the history of the lands, which are dealt with therein. ... the contention of the respondents that under the Foras Act they acquired a specific right to hold the lands on payment of assessment not exceeding what was then payable, must, therefore, be accepted

issues.text: Whether the land acquisition proceedings under Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 extinguished the right of the Government to levy assessment on the lands.

anchor.surface_text: We have next to decide what effect the proceedings taken by the Government under the Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 during the years 1864 to 1867 have on the rights of the parties. Section VIII of the Act is as follows When the Collector or other officer has made an award or directed a reference to arbitration, be may take immediate possession of the land which shall thenceforward be vested absolutely in the Government, free from all other estates, rights, titles and interests.

issues.text: Whether the sale deed Exhibit A imposes any limitation on the right of the Crown to assess the lands or conveys them revenue-free.

anchor.surface_text: Then there remains the question whether the sale deed, Exhibit A, imposes any limitation on the right of the Crown to assess the lands. The deed conveys the lands to the purchasers absolutely with all rights, easements and appurtenances whatsoever to be held for ever. It does not, however, recite that they are to be held revenue-free.

issues.text: Whether the assessment leviable under section 8 of Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876 is limited to the rate payable under the Foras Act No. VI of 1851 notwithstanding the land acquisition and sale under Exhibit A.

anchor.surface_text: It was finally contended that even if the land acquisition proceedings between 1864 and 1867 had not the effect of extinguishing the right of the Government to levy assessment, and that even if Exhibit A conferred on the purchasers no right to hold the land revenue-free, the assessment which the Government was entitled to levy under section 8 of Act No. II of 1876 was limited to what was payable under the Foras Act No. VI of 1851

anchor.surface_text: Construing that section, the Privy Council laid down in Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v. Collector of Bombay two propositions that though the language of the section would more appropriately apply when the dispute was as to the quantum of assessment, the right to levy it not being itself controverted, it was open to the superior holder under this section to plead and prove that the State had no right to levy any assessment and that the burden was on the person who pleaded a limitation on the right of the State to assess, to clearly and unequivocally establish it.

precedents.case_name: Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v. Collector of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: though the language of the section would more appropriately apply when the dispute was as to the quantum of assessment, the right to levy it not being itself controverted, it was open to the superior holder under this section to plead and prove that the State had no right to levy any assessment and that the burden was on the person who pleaded a limitation on the right of the State to assess, to clearly and unequivocally establish it

anchor.surface_text: In the Matter of the Land Acquisition Act The Government of Bombay v. precedents.case_name: The Government of Bombay v. Esupali Salebhai
precedents.cited_proposition: Government not debarred from acquiring only outstanding interests; does not acquire its own interest

precedents.citation: Deputy Collector, Calicut Division v. Aiyavu Pillay 1

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Deputy Collector, Calicut Division v. Aiyavu Pillay 1 , Wallis, J.  as he then was  observed It is, in my opinion, clear that the Act does not contemplate or provide for the acquisition of any interest which already belongs to Government in land which is being acquired under the Act, but only for the acquisition of such interests in the land as do not already belong to the Government.

precedents.case_name: Deputy Collector, Calicut Division v. Aiyavu Pillay
precedents.cited_proposition: Land Acquisition Act does not contemplate acquisition of Government's own interest in land
